content.description: Sidepull the vertical rail to gain nice feet. Mantel up to the ledge, and continue up left of the bolts on nice edges to a short slab section. Slap the sloper to another ledge and the anchors, 6 bolts.
content.protection: 6 draws and something for the anchors.
content.location: It is the first bolted route on the left.

content.description: Climb up the bulge to clip the first bolt. Climb over the second bulge to an overhang. This will be easier for taller people to grab the jug over the roof. After the roof is the headwall crux. Balance up on little feet and hands. Climb the slab to the anchors
content.location:
This is the route just right of

B52 Chimney

.

content.description: Climb the slab to a ledge with a bulge. Grab a nice crimp on top of the bulge to mantel up for a nice jug. Trend left and up the right side or directly up the water groove to the anchors, 6 bolts.
content.protection: 6 draws and something for the anchors.
content.location: This is the fourth bolted route from the right.

content.description:
Climb the slab on nice edges to a ledge. Undercling to get feet for the last short, balancy slab. You can clip the last bolt of

Unicorns Fart Rainbows

or run it out to the anchors. This shares anchors with

Unicorns Fart Rainbows

, 6 bolts.
content.location: This is the second bolted climb to the right.

content.description: Climb the double cracks until it gets wider at the top but eases off in difficulty
content.protection: Trad gear and a bolted anchor at the top.
content.location: This route is on the far west end of this formation. On the old fire tower trail from the lower west side intersection, continuing up the old fire tower trail. In a few hundred feet, you will see the double cracks off to your left.

content.description: Climb the slab on nice edges and good feet to a ledge. Undercling the bulge to get a foot smear so you can get good holds above the bulge. Traverse right, and mantel up under the crack. Two finger crack moves will get you to the anchor. It has 5 bolts.
content.protection: 5 draws and something for the anchors.
content.location: It is the first bolted route from the left.

content.description: Start by stemming in the left corner. Sidepulls and underclings take you to the right through the first crux. Mantel up for a rest before cranking through the final crux. A three finger crimp will get you to a powerful undercling, then layback all the way to the chains.
content.location: This route is extremely hard to find. Essentially it's northwest about 200 yards from Unicorn Valley Wall. It's totally surrounded by walls of rock. Look for the Guillotine chockstone, and you will find it.

content.description: Climb the slab to get under the bulge. The first crux is getting established over the lip of the second bulge. The second crux is getting over the headwall above to get on the slab. Climb the slab with generously spaced bolts to the anchors.
content.location: It is the farthest right bolted climb on the west-facing wall.

content.description:
The first 50 feet of the route is a little dirty but will clean up with time, but there are some great jams along the way and a first crux, 5.8. Go under the giant car-size chockstone into the tunnel where you can look up at the second squeeze chimney crux, 5.8. You can get some gear in horizontal crack on either side of the chimney as you make your way up. Bring a #6 cam or a Bigbro unless you want to run it out like I did.

The first pitch is about 150 feet to the anchors. The second pitch is the crux of the route and is only about 60 feet long. A wide bottom leads to an offwidth section that I did with my left side in.
content.protection: Trad gear, bring a #6 Camalot or Bigbro unless you feel comfortable running out the chimney section. Smaller climbers will have an easier time here as they will fit right in the crack. There are bolted anchors.
content.location:
This route is the huge, right-facing dihedral on the far left of the wall with the giant chockstone in it.

Rap 3 times to get down. The second rap is a rope stretcher, so be very careful, and you go over several roofs. So to get to the last rap anchors on the top of the sport routes on Unicorn Valley, you have to swing in to get on the ledge. This swing might be hard for some, so you can also rap down the second pitch and walk climber's left on the huge ledge, under the rock, then walk clockwise around the formation to get back to the base of the climb.

content.description: Climb the slab to a ledge. Balance over the bulge to another ledge. Climb the arete left of the water groove to the anchors, 8 bolts.
content.protection: 8 draws and something for the anchors.
content.location: This is the third bolted route to the right.

content.description: Start under the overhanging rock that's on the right. Good hand jams and lots of features get you through the first bulge. The second wide bulge is the crux. Bring really wide gear or run it out to the anchors
content.location: This is the wide crack on the far right side of Unicorn Valley.

content.description:
Climb a nice hand crack to a ledge. Layback a finger-size crack to another ledge. Two moves up the next finger crack will get you to the anchors. This route shares anchors with

Jumping On The Bed

.
content.protection:
Trad gear. You can clip the last bolt of

Jumping On The Bed

or use good gear in the crack.
content.location: This is the farthest route to the right.

content.description: Stem and chimney up the wide slot. This is still very dirty.
content.protection: You can get small gear in the back of the crack. There are bolted anchors at the top.
content.location: This route is on the far west end of this formation. On the old fire tower trail from the lower west side intersection, continuing up the old fire tower trail. In a few hundred feet, you will see the double cracks off to your left.
